page.title: 13Swanscombe Chalk Pits
page.content: { }The Cement Industry which began in the early 19th century is still active at Swanscombe. Here there are two large chalk quarries which cover about 580 acres. Clearly visible from the road they are bounded to the south by the Old Watling Street and bisected by Bean Road. A potential hazard, they are protected from the public by warning notices and fences. Mechanical face shovels and crushers have long since replaced manual methods of extraction. Residents nearby complain of dust. Clay, the other main constituent of cement, is mixed with water and piped in liquid state under the River Thames from Essex to the Swanscombe Works. Ground chalk is then mixed in to it to form a slurry, which is in turn piped to the Northfleet plant for kiln drying and the completion of the cement-making.
